awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Sustainable Censorship Resistance Systems for the Next Decade
awd_abstract_narration:
The Internet enables people around the world to communicate, fostering free speech,  a free press, and democracy.  For billions of people, however, the freedom to communicate via the Internet is regulated, monitored and restricted by governments or corporations.  To combat such censorship, researchers have designed and deployed a variety of censorship circumvention systems. Unfortunately, such systems have been designed based on ad hoc heuristics (rather than on solid, theoretical foundations) and can be defeated by typical state-level censors. This research project is developing theory, methodologies, and tools to formally design, evaluate, and compare censorship resistance systems. 

The researchers are developing a formal model for the Internet censorship problem based on theoretical foundations. In particular, they are deriving a standard set of metrics for modeling the parties involved in each Internet censorship scenario,  and leverage game theory, network science, and information theory for the analysis of specific censorship resistance systems. An important part of this project is the design and deployment of effective censorship resistance systems that will provide reliable, sustainable censorship resistance to Internet users. One approach being targeted by the researchers is leveraging emerging communication paradigms such as content caching, mobility, and cloud computing in the design of censorship circumvention tools. The second approach targeted by the researchers is adapting the design of circumvention systems to the architectural evolutions of the Internet. Specifically, the researchers are investigating the impacts of software-defined networking (SDN) and network functions virtualization (NFV) on Internet censorship and adapting the design of circumvention systems to ensure sustainable circumvention performance for the future.

por.por_cntn:
The Internet plays a crucial role in today’s social and political movements by facilitating the free circulation of speech, information, and ideas; democracy and human rights throughout the world critically depend on preserving and bolstering the Internet’s openness. Consequently, repressive regimes, totalitarian governments, and corrupt corporations regulate, monitor, and restrict access to the Internet, which is broadly known as Internet censorship. Therefore, Internet freedom has been an official foreign-policy priority for the United States, and it has been recognized as a human right by the United Nations. However, reports on the state of Internet freedom anticipate Internet censorship to remain the biggest global threat to the freedom of speech, democracy, and human rights in the years to come. This goal of this project was to produce theory, methodologies, and tools to formally design, evaluate, and compare censorship resistance systems. Towards this goal, this project took several complementary directions, as outlined in the following.  

Motivated by the lack of systemization in the research area of Internet censorship, this project took several directions towards formalizing the Internet censorship problem based on solid theoretical foundations. We leveraged several theoretical approaches to analyze and optimize circumvention. In particular, we demonstrated that using a game theoretic analysis can lead to circumvention systems with optimized performances. Our theoretical foundations can provide circumvention users with rigorous guarantees on the privacy, security, and performance of in-the-wild circumvention systems they use.

Sustainable circumvention technologies of tomorrow will need to adapt to the forthcoming changes in the Internet’s architecture and deployment, as well as evolutions in its communication paradigms. Towards this, this project investigated the use of emerging communication paradigms, such as cloud computing, content caching, and mobility, in the design of more resilient censorship resistance technologies for the evolving Internet of the future. This project also investigated the impact of architectural changes of the Internet, in particular next-generation Internet architectures, on Internet censorship and circumvention. The project led to the development of the MassBrowser circumvention system, which aims to improve resilience by getting help from typical Internet users.

Improving cybersecurity education and mentoring was a key component of the proposed project —both within academia and in the society. This includes integrating topics in cybersecurity into undergraduate and graduate computer science curricula, involving undergraduates, women, and under-represented minorities in advanced cybersecurity research, and educating high-school and freshman college students on the privacy risks of surfing online and the ethics of cybersecurity. The project also contributed to the global awareness about Internet censorship by posting regular blog posts and interviews aimed at typical Internet users.
